Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Fast Focus-scanning Microscopy Using Micron-thick phase Plates Based on High-index Meta-structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Faraon
1512266

Understanding how the brain works is one of the main scientific challenges of this generation. Optical techniques for neural imaging, excitation and recording play a crucial role in deconstructing the neural circuitry. Optical modulation and recording from sets of neurons is enabled by optogenetics and genetically encoded voltage sensors. To fully use this capability, the PI proposes to develop a fast and slim device capable of focusing light in a volume on the same order of magnitude as a cortical column at speeds faster than an action potential and spatial resolution smaller than a neuronal cell body.

The enabling technology is the recent invention of dielectric meta-surfaces, structures thinner than a wavelength that allow for unprecedented control of free-space propagating light. The uniqueness of the technology stems from the capability to lithographically place the phase plates in very close proximity (tens of microns) and to actuate them at high speeds using electrostatic forces like in micro electro-mechanical devices (MEMS). If successful, this project will enable devices that could scan many neurons in a cortical column with single action potential temporal resolution, thus resulting in deconstruction of neural circuitry in that column.

This interdisciplinary project will provide the opportunity to train a graduate student in nano-photonics and biomicroscopy. The student will simulate and fabricate the devices, will develop a complex microscope setup, and will do two-photon microscopy measurements on brain samples. In addition to graduate student education, undergraduate students will contribute to the project through the SURF program at Caltech. The PI and the graduate student will be involved in an outreach activity with the Navajo Preparatory High School, a native American high school located in Farmington, New Mexico. The activity will consist in travelling to Farmington to teach science lessons, describing the research, and setting up demonstrations for high school students visiting Caltech.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Understanding how the brain works is one of the main scientific challenges of this generation. Optical techniques for neural imaging, excitation and recording will play a crucial role in deconstructing the neural circuitry. Today, optical modulation and recording from sets of neurons is enabled by optogenetics and genetically encoded voltage sensors. However, to fully use this capability, optical technologies that allow for high-speed and high-resolution in-vivo light delivery and imaging must be further developed. In this project we developed a fast and slim device capable of focusing light in a volume on the same order of magnitude as a cortical column. The slim and lightweight characteristics will enable implantation on rodent skulls. The enabling technology is the recent invention of dielectric meta-surfaces, structures thinner than a wavelength that allow for unprecedented control of free-space propagating light. Our group has previously demonstrated micron-thick phase plates (lenses) that could be assembled in sub-millimeter thick optical systems with fast tunable focus. Based on this technology, in this project we demonstrated an optical system composed of two lenses where the focus is scanned by moving the plates with respect to each other like in a telescopic system. The uniqueness of our technology stems from the capability to lithographically place the phase plates in very close proximity (tens of microns) and to actuate them at high speeds using electrostatic forces like in micro electro-mechanical devices (MEMS). This is a versatile platform that can be applied to various types of microscopy.

 

Specifically, we demonstrated tunable metasurface doublets, based on microelectromechanical systems (MEMS), with more than 60 diopters (about 4%) change in the optical power upon a 1-μm movement of one metasurface, and a scanning frequency that can potentially reach a few kHz. They can also be integrated with a third metasurface to make compact microscopes (~1 mm thick) with a large corrected field of view (~500 μm or 40 degrees) and fast axial scanning for 3D imaging. This paves the way towards MEMS-integrated metasurfaces as a platform for tunable and reconfigurable optics. In addition to the tunable metasurface lens doublet we demonstrated two photon microscopy using a double wavelength metasurface lens, thus showing the potential of this technology for biological experiments. 

 

Intellectual merit: As a result of this project we now have a better understanding of how meta-surfaces can be used in imaging applications, microscopy in particular. Metasurfaces are new optical elements, that only how are starting to be integrated in complex optical systems. Their optical properties such as chromatic aberration and coma was characterized. Integration of meta-surfaces with micro electro-mechanical systems was developed.

 

Broader Impact. Advancing optical imaging techniques is indispensable for accelerating research in neural sciences. Neuroscience will allow us to understand the largely unknown underlying mechanisms of psychiatric diseases that currently have a tremendous impact on our society. This may lead to finding cures for these diseases, with a highly positive impact both on our wellbeing and our economy. This project provided the opportunity to train a graduate student in nano-photonics and biomicroscopy. It required the student to understand and use techniques from optical engineering, nano-fabrication, nano-photonics and high-resolution microscopy. The student simulated and fabricated the devices and developed a complex microscope setup. In addition to graduate student education, an undergraduate student contributed to the project through the Summer Undergraduate Research Fellowship program at Caltech
